title: When will total cases of COVID-19 in Canada reach 2 million or more, according to the Public Health Agency of Canada (PHAC)?
preds:
In reality, probably getting close to 2 million already. We really don't know what our true numbers ours - Canada doesn't have the testing capacity of other countries like Denmark. Level of COVID fatigue will probably stop a certain percentage of population from getting tested anyways. Rapid tests also adding an element of confusion.
Holiday season will probably generate a rapid spike.

1,907,771, 92,229 to go
30 day to 22 Jan
3k per day needed
Current cases at 6k per day
At this rate and increasing cases it looks like we’ll get there in early Jan. Oops I should have kept an eye on this and updated earlier.

The jump in numbers would have me guessing just before or on December 31st, but 24th is too early.  https://montrealgazette.com/news/local-news/covid-19-updates-montreal-quebec-new-cases-vaccine-vaccination-booster-shot-omicron-christmas-party-record-restrictions-christmas-december-21
1,896,426 Dec 21. 7 day is 5971 and omicron is just starting to go. Bin 2 it is
Testing is so swamped, there's no way they'll get to 2.0M in bin 1.

Ok, I was probably foolish to put so much weight on bin 1. If it weren't for testing capacity, I do think Canada would get there.
For example: "Testing is definitely breaking down. People testing positive on rapid test and cannot book a PCR test within 150 km radius for the next week (Ottawa area). I agree that cases and positivity are much higher than reported."
https://twitter.com/FroatsStephanie/status/1472674648433307656

Increased outcome 1 a wee bit because it was tracking up near my worst case scenario.  At this rate just the Ontario numbers could get us to the target before the 26th if the restrictions that are coming in don't make a difference. oh the difference 2 days can make

Same forecast as before. I think Canada would record 2.0M cases before Dec 24 if testing backlogs and reporting weren't an issue, but they are. Still, leaving 5% on bin 1 in case of a surprise. With current case growth, I'd expect to see 2.0M on Dec 24, without testing and reporting issues.

Reverting with thanks to @SE_Meyer pointing out an error
Total expected 1.935 - 1.965M by 23rd December inclusive, worst case 1.997M
Expecting 2.0M to be reached 5-14 days later
It seems implausible but I can see the possibility of 1.958-2.015M by 24th

Cases are starting to pick up now. If we take as likely a scenario similar to Europe where countries are seeing pandemic record numbers of cases we could expect cases to reach >10k a day soon. With the current total number of cases being 142013, it would take ~14 days of 10k cases a day to make it to 2m total cases. This makes Bin 1 very unlikely unless there is a massive spike, but Bin 2 seems reasonable with some leeway for cases to increase and decreases following a peak at 10-15k.

I do think 2.0M cases would be reached in bin 1 if it weren't for the holidays and testing limitations. I think Omicron will soon saturate testing capabilities in a lot of places.
(Also note that QC, the province with the most cases and probably the biggest backlog, isn't going to report data 6 days over the holidays: https://twitter.com/sante_qc/status/1471877823887548417 )

Total cases to 16th December 1.858M
I think social behavioural changes will gradually start to affect the doubling rate within 2-3 days (due to rising awareness of risk), and imposed restrictions a few days later. Expecting another few days of record rises before this happens, but a total a little below 2.0M on 24th December.
Quebec: New restrictions to start from Monday include reducing venue capacity to 50%, as cases pass 2,700 (with estimated 20% Omicron):
https://montrealgazette.com/news/local-news/covid-19-updates-montreal-quebec-new-cases-vaccine-vaccination-booster-shot-omicron-lockdown-holiday-party-travel-december-16
Ontario: No new restrictions yet but possible circuit breaker and extreme caution advised after 2,421 new cases reported:
https://globalnews.ca/news/8455467/ontario-covid-cases-december-16-coronavirus/
New Brunswick: Single day high 177, after 160 new cases yesterday and 11 Omicron on 15th:
https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/new-brunswick/covid-19-new-brunswick-record-high-cases-shephard-omicron-1.6287983
Manitoba: New restrictions from Monday after a new recent high of 216 cases recorded yesterday:
https://winnipeg.ctvnews.ca/manitoba-records-over-200-covid-19-cases-largest-single-day-total-since-june-1.5710211
https://www.ctvnews.ca/health/coronavirus/canadians-urged-to-get-covid-19-booster-jabs-as-omicron-concerns-grow-1.5711194 Without behavioural changes it could exceed 2.0M but I expect a final range of 1.935 - 1.965M by 24th December, 2.0M reached 4-12 days later

https://twitter.com/EdTubb/status/1471515800787951619
I think Omicron would cause enough cases to reach 2.0M in bin 1, but I suspect that testing will be saturated before that's possible.

Damn you Omicron. For a refreshing POV that doesn’t originate from a North American or European source see:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RWrjX1ty2EU
In his analysis, the gentleman interviewed appears to tick several of the “Good Judgement” boxes. Plus, Freddie Sayers (the interviewer) didn’t let him off easy. Hopefully UnHerd will invite him back in 3 – 4 weeks time to see how accurate his forecast was.

I do think the schedule for bin 1 is probably too tight, but I'm not completely sure yet.
"Ontario could see 10,000 new COVID-19 cases daily by NYE as Omicron variant takes over: science table head"
https://twitter.com/CP24/status/1471168886573776899
Doubling time 2.2 days, 53.0% Omicron, ~917 Omicron cases today, Delta seems to have peaked (Rt = 0.97):
https://covid19-sciencetable.ca/ontario-dashboard/ If we estimate ~2500 total Omicron cases in Ontario as of yesterday and ~900 today, and use a doubling time of 2.2 days, that would add ~51k Omicron cases by Dec 24. Add Delta on top. And other provinces, which can't be far behind. There's only 155k to go. But there are the holidays coming up, too. Later edit: Let's suppose that there were 2000 Omicron cases in Canada on Dec 15. Doubling time = 2.2 days, case rate increases by 37% per day => 120k more Omicron cases by Dec 24. Add in 30k-40k more Delta cases, and Canada could reach 2.0M by Dec 24. There is uncertainty in the number of Omicron cases today and in the doubling time for the country as a whole, and this calculation is very sensitive to different values for those numbers, but 2.0M is possible. As of the end of Dec 15, including Dec 15 numbers, 148,943 additional cases need to be added to reach 2.0M. Also, 2386 cases in Québec today vs. 1731 in Ontario. I think QC will be doing the heaviest lifting on actual Omicron cases soon. Their surveillance seems light years behind Ontario's, but their Omicron cases are probably very little behind. Lots of reports of Omicron outbreaks in QC over the past couple days at schools, etc. Otoh, their surveillance is *so* far behind that they have a 4-day (and growing!) testing backlog: https://twitter.com/ThomasGerbet/status/1471088803309834240
They might not contribute comparatively many reported cases to this question because of their testing constraints. We'll see.
Today's numbers being lower than they could have been point even more strongly to Outcome 1 not being believable

Forecasts for Ontario aren't high enough for Canada to reach 2M in bin 1 after all. False alarm. Sorry, people.
https://twitter.com/DFisman/status/1470723274158088197 Later edit: I've seen other predictions that are quite different. I think bin 1 is possible.

First bucket is infeasible. Second bucket would be easily hit given 3 day doubling time for Omicron plus the current 7 day average rate, and considering the rate was increasing pre Omicron, this looks overwhelmingly likely. If not, it's hard to imagine a scenario that doesn't at least land in the third bucket.

After a flurry of research and a quick analysis last night (UK) I have a more simplistic but measured review:
Ontario and Quebec contribute ~75% of all cases in Canada (approx 1500 Ontario + 2000 Quebec = 3500 out of 4700 for Canada) and the proportion is growing.
Ontario now has ~30% Omicron prevalence, lets say 500 cases, doubling roughly every 3 days = ~40-60k further cases (possibly higher?) by 24th December.
Plus the 1000 Delta cases climbing approx 25% by 24th (a broad guess) = 15000. So total for Ontario loosely 55-75k.
Quebec has cases rising, but only 14 reported as Omicron https://montrealgazette.com/news/quebec/covid-outlook , so a much lower base level. On that basis I only project perhaps 20-25k additional Omicron cases and 30k Delta by 24th = 50-55k.
So very roughly 105-130k additional cases to be added from those two provinces, while the remainder are flat v short term, adding perhaps another 15-20k.
Total Canada 120-150k, with 172k needed for bin1. Still worryingly close and plenty of room for error, given my very basic math, but not as certain as I had thought last night. Edit: I’ve noticed a miscalculation for Quebec, so the total would be lower than stated

so to update to 13th data of 1841k total cases gives 159k to go https://health-infobase.canada.ca/covid-19/epidemiological-summary-covid-19-cases.html?stat=num&measure=total&map=pt#a2
Ontario had 453 cases of Omicron (doubling in 3 days) and 1019 cases of delta (doubling in 40 days) https://covid19-sciencetable.ca/ontario-dashboard/
Quebec looks just as bad https://www.quebec.ca/en/health/health-issues/a-z/2019-coronavirus/situation-coronavirus-in-quebec
but doesn't do the same level of sequencing it seems with a one off sequencing trial done on 30th of Nov https://www.inspq.qc.ca/covid-19/donnees/variants
looking at the rate of change it would be a rash forecaster that still thinks they have only 8 cases of omicron if you model Ontario using those start numbers above and add 1/3rd of Omicron and 1/42nd of delta each day then it gets to another 43k by the 23rd (ie before the 24th). assuming that Quebec is about the same then would get another 48k.
Currently these two states are about 75% of cases but there is no reason to expect all other areas to grow as exponentially (though some likely will)
Might end up with 90k more cases which is only just over half what is needed. 
Omicron cases would have to go up by somewhere between 45% each day to make the 159k from just ontario and quebec

Update for Ontario today: Omicron now causes 30.8% of cases, Rt = 4.01, doubling time 3 days: https://covid19-sciencetable.ca/ontario-dashboard/
Also: https://www.cbc.ca/news/politics/omicron-rapidly-escalate-canada-1.6284011 I am not certain about this forecast, as you can see by the split. Ontario seems to have the worst Omicron situation so far in Canada, although there are limited data to go by. Let's focus on Ontario alone for a moment. On Dec 13, they had an estimated 1472 cases/day (https://covid19-sciencetable.ca/ontario-dashboard/ ). Let's estimate that 0.308 * 1472 = 453 were Omicron, and 1019 = ~1k were Delta (using https://twitter.com/DFisman/status/1470485244528795648 ). Based on similar calculations for earlier dates, Delta cases are still increasing. But supposing that Delta cases hold constant (I think it's more likely they'll continue to increase), then this would mean ~95% cases Omicron by Christmas => ~20k total cases/day, or ~19k Omicron cases/day, just in Ontario. So that could add ~90k Omicron cases in Ontario alone by Dec 24. Meanwhile, as of Dec 10, there are only 172k more cases to go for Canada to reach 2.0M (from official question resolution data), and 14 more days of data for bin 1. If one assumes that almost none of the 3.2k/day as of Dec 9 is due to Omicron, then we can conservatively project 3k * 14 = 42k additional Delta cases in bin 1, although there will likely be more (up to 50k?). (Note that I am assuming that Omicron cases don't replace Delta so much as become superimposed on Delta.) 172k - 42k - 90k = 40k. Given that there were 4692 cases on Dec 13 ( https://health-infobase.canada.ca/covid-19/epidemiological-summary-covid-19-cases.html ) and that Ontario represented only 31% of Canada's cases today, I think it would not be unreasonable to expect the rest of Canada to contribute 40k Omicron cases in bin 1. This is not a slam dunk, but I do think bin 1 is likelier than bin 2.

What a change a day can make.
cases growing in Ontario with 30% of cases now Omicron
Quebec cases growing even faster but they haven't put out the omicron data yet. Unbelievably, even with such a fast increase in case numbers Quebec has said that people don't need to change christmas plans just yet
https://www.thestar.com/politics/provincial/2021/12/13/omicrons-spread-forcing-changes-at-ontario-nursing-homes-and-to-booster-schedules.html
https://www.thestar.com/politics/2021/12/13/omicron-high-daily-cases-should-not-affect-plans-to-ease-rules-for-holidays-legault.html
Probationary update. Overall philosophy remains same until I get to recheck the data later.

Current total cases 1.828M as of December 10th. Could there be an additional 172k by 23rd? It’s a question I wouldn’t have asked before Omicron, with the 7-day average rate below 3,800, and needing to average 13,300/day for bin1.
But Ontario has just reported 1536 new cases yesterday, with an expected doubling rate of around three days.  https://www.google.co.uk/amp/s/www.cbc.ca/amp/1.6283521
And Quebec reported 2013 on Friday last week, and just less on Saturday and Sunday, with some community transmission:
https://www.google.co.uk/amp/s/montrealgazette.com/news/quebec/covid-outlook/wcm/66f1644c-ab62-4067-81a4-96e1987a6ce1/amp/
Both provinces are over 75% fully vaccinated (by population) but this is proving to provide less immunity than against Delta, and may not slow transmission without other measures.
Unless the doubling rate slows to 4-5 days Ontario will likely add ~90k by 24th and Quebec could perhaps add even more (needs qualifying). Other provinces have marginally declining cases but not by enough to affect such a tidal wave. It’s hard to accept bin1 is not only a contender, it is likely.

Just Ontario:
https://twitter.com/DFisman/status/1470440656992677892
https://twitter.com/DFisman/status/1470485244528795648 It's going to take me a bit to wrap my head around this new reality. I need to think about this some more, but bin 1 is starting to look inevitable.
@probahilliby @GMR @Scappleby

High vaccination rates look less effective against Omicron than they were against Delta, while booster doses have become more critical. Ontario and Quebec cases are starting to climb rapidly, and may well be an indicator of what's to come.

Maybe a bit confident on 2
I'll wait for the Omicron swing
Gonna go for a big jump up for bin 2. Pretty confident can't get bin 1

160k to go with 13 days remaining in bin 1; I don't think Omicron can do that, but I'm not going to rule it out. Cases would have to grow substantially faster than in their April 2021 wave. Reasons why they could: 1. that was Alpha, and this is Omicron; 2. that was spring, and this is fall/winter. Reason why they probably won't: substantially reduced reported around the holidays.
42 days left for bin 2 => 160k/42 = 3.8k/day average. Omicron will do that. Cases are looking pretty exponential. Meanwhile, in Finland: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1347783
Based on changes since I last forecast but have yet to model the growth to make sure I am being realistic
Have to accept Omicron is very likely to add significant cases by January.

1,818,742 today
181,258 to go
22 Jan = 44 days = 4,120 per day
Current rate = 3.2k per day
Rate is creeping up and if there is a spike it could still get there before 22 Jan, but still waiting evidence that there will be a big enough spike.
Keeping in mind that every day the current rate is below the required rate, the next day the required rate increases.
But I did get caught out previously on this view by not keeping a close enough eye on numbers when the relationship changed direction!

EDIT:
projected resolution (as of 11 Dec '21 ): 17 January 2022
projected resolution (as of 16 Dec '21 ): 08 January 2022
projected resolution (as of 21 Dec '21 ): 31 December 2021
final: projected resolution (as of 22 Dec '21 ): 26 December 2021

Omicron. I should have updated this forecast a few days ago....
180k left to go. 48 days to Jan 22. Currently 3k cases/day and growing somewhat slowly. If Delta cases continue to grow over the next month, they'll add 180k. But I think it doesn't matter if Delta winds down, because Omicron will wind up, faster than people will react. It's possible that Omicron could add >400k cases by Jan 22, although I'd hope that some mitigations would be put in place, and I'd also hope that seasonality would help out some. But I'm not optimistic that Canada will still be under 2M by Jan 22.
Extrapolation estimate of logarithmic current case rate
Not enough time to get to that number by Jan 22 and believing the rate is increasing and using scappleby’s forecast rationale(well done!) I will be bolder

1,798,872 as of Dec 2. 7 day avg of 2863 and trending slowly up over the last month.
So... on one hand we've got Omicron... on the other we have the Children's vaccine roll out. On one side we've got holidays and social gatherings, on the other we have school out, which may help slow the spread (a bit), and there's been talk of extending the break again if numbers surge.
Current rate puts it 70 days out, or Feb 11. With 10 days to the next bin it now seems prudent to put the highest odds in there, and with that date 3 weeks past the prior bin it certainly seems most likely. With 50 days to Jan 22 cases would have to surpass 4k/day, which is possible but would require a significant surge, and not knowing what Omicron will do, I'll overweight it as a hedge. To go past Feb 22 it would have to be below 2470, which would mean cases have stabilized again... so also possible and slightly more likely than bin 1. I'm rooting for bin 3 now but the data is pointing strongly to 2
Every region is now growing in numbers. Made an adjustment towards lower outcomes based on these optics. Will model it a bit more carefully for next update

Perhaps counter intuitively I'm expecting concerns over Omicron to help reduce cases over the next few weeks, even though testing itself may increase in the lead up to Christmas. Vaccination rates have tapered, but fully vaccinated levels are now over 75.5%, which is 86% of the population over 12 yrs old. I'm aware Omicron has shown alarming signs of vaccine escape, but I think Canadians measured response to date and their 86% full-dose level  could be just enough to prevent any rapid spread of the new variant. Alternatively numbers could continue to climb as transmission of Omicron gradually increases. Two cases have been traced in Ontario (3 days ago) for example, and they are working to prevent any further seeding. https://www.nbcnews.com/news/world/omicron-variant-now-north-america-canadian-officials-say-rcna6881
Ontario is already vaccinating 5-12yr olds however, and has covered 9.4% of this group, which looks to be where most transmission intakes place, in the last couple of weeks. They could reach 20% by year end. Any counter measures will help, so I find it too early to call whether numbers will climb exponentially, but given the context I think any spread will be slow to start. Then it will depend on current vaccine efficacy and immunity levels, combined with social mixing over the holiday period.

1.792m
Cases hovering around 2.7k per day
208k to go
Before 23 Jan = 54 days = 3,852 per day
Before 22 Feb = 84 days = 2,476 per day
Before 24 Mar = days = 1,285 per day Given how far rates have to rise or fall (consistently) I see it as hard to not resolve in bin 3.
Yes Omicron might cause a huge surge, so we will need to keep an eye out, but it depends how big that surge is, assuming it happens.
Keeping forecast in bin 3 with a little increase to bin 2.
All other bins seem really unlikely right now.
Re-checked and corrected work. Simple extrapolation using Excel shows 2 million cases 90 days from last data point of Nov 23 2021
Updated forecast based on latest data available from Statista as at Nov 23 2021. Of course Omicron could change everything...
Omicron.  Overall, the cases need to begin exceeding 3,800 cases/day to cross 2M cases as of Jan 22. Possible, but I'm still cautiously optimistic.

As of November 22, 2021, there had been around 1.77 million confirmed coronavirus cases and 29,526 deaths from the disease in Canada (https://www.statista.com/statistics/1107034/covid19-cases-deaths-tests-canada/.  Daily case counts in November ranged from a low of 1851 (Nov 2) to a high of 4162 (Nov 25)(https://www.statista.com/statistics/1107034/covid19-cases-deaths-tests-canada In the past 4 months cases grew by approxl 110,000 each month:
Aug 26 (1,475,978) Sept 26 (1,594,202) Oct  26 (1,704,000) and Nov 26 (1,790,000)
https://www.google.com/search?q=daily+covid+count+canada&rlz=1C1GCEB_enCA822CA822&oq=daily+covid+count+canada&aqs=chrome..69i57j0i22i30l3j0i390l3.4032j0j15&sourceid=chrome&ie=UTF-8 Those who are getting covid are more likley to be women in their 20s
Vaccination numbers continue to grow, those fully vaccinated (12 +) account for 78% and those who have one dose (12+) account for 89.260. https://health-infobase.canada.ca/covid-19/epidemiological-summary-covid-19-cases.html#a3 There is also a new variant of the coronavirus  reported from South Africa,  The W.H.O. said the new variant was “of concern” and gave it the name Omicron. A variant of concern has mutations that are significant to public health and could: spread more easily
cause more severe illness
require different treatments, or
reduce vaccine effectiveness The newly identified variant, apparently has a “very unusual constellation of mutations,” (Tulio de Oliveira, director of the KwaZulu-Natal Research and Innovation Sequencing Platform). The new variant has 10 mutations. In comparison, the Beta variant has three and the Delta variant two https://www.nytimes.com/2021/11/26/us/coronavirus-briefing-what-happened-today-omnicon-new-variant-south-africa.html While there is no proof yet that the variant could diminish the protective power of the vaccines but if we compare it to the spread of the Delta variant, which spread rapidly through India, wand Great Britain before reaching the U.S. and Canada where it quickly surged. It is now the predominant SARS CoV-2 variant, accounting for more than 99% of COVID-19 cases and leading to an overwhelming increase in hospitalizations https://www.yalemedicine.org/news/5-things-to-know-delta-variant-covid  People who are not vaccinated are most at risk, and the highest spread of cases and severe outcomes is happening in places with low vaccination rates.  However there is evidece of waning  immunity over time and it is expected that the ability of vaccines to protect against initial infection will gradually weaken https://www.cbc.ca/news/health/covid-19-fall-winter-forecast-1.6185069but

1.782m
Cases hovering around 2.5k per day
218k to go
3.5k/day = 62 days = 29 jan
3k / day = 73 days = 9 feb
2.5k / day = 87 days = 24 Feb
2k / day = 109 days = 17 mar
1.5k / day = 145 days = after 23 apr (just) Still believe Feb is most likely but as rates have not been dropping off as expected and the risk of risking infections seems a bit higher at the moment bringing likely range earlier rather than later. Even at current rates of just over 2.5k per day this likely brings us before 22 Feb.
Rethinking based on the possible Omicron influence increasing numbers from mid-December through Jan

Omicron could start to make a big dent by mid- to late January, depending on how many cases are already in Canada. Given that 61 people just tested positive for Covid on 2 flights from SA to Amsterdam and that most of those cases will be Omicron, there could easily already be 1k cases in Canada from flights from SA, Malawi and other places where Omicron is spreading that we don't know about yet. With an estimated doubling time of 4.8 days in the spring in SA currently, and ~1/3 of cases being detected, Omicron could cause ~58k reported cases by Jan 21, with very large error bars. All of this is very sensitive to how many cases are currently in the country, of course, on how quickly it spreads, and on whether restrictions are put in place to slow its spread.

I am inclined to put more weight on the months of February and March and the months adjacent. However, other calibrated forecasters seem to be putting more weight on later bins. In addition, it is reasonable that the rate could slow to the extent that it starts to include the weeks following "Not before 23 April 2022."

There are around 2.500 cases each day. If this would stay at this level, it would take 90 days until we reach the mark of 2 million (23 February). I expect that numbers more likely will rise than fall (see what happened last year and what happens now in Europe). At least it is highly unlikely that numbers are declining rapidly. So I give it a 95% chance, that the mark is reached by 23 March.  This would mean an average case number of around 1.900 or above. If we would stay at around 2.500 for the rest of the year, even an average of 1.650 until from 1 January to 23 March would be enough.

~1.76m total and 7 day avg is 2373 and flat. Current numbers put it ~100 days out, or late Feb. Winter means indoors and closer contact, which could increase rate, but vaccine for 5-11 should roll out soon and slow spread further. I'll stick with current forecast.

I think cases will track in a narrow band, perhaps marginally higher, through December. Vaccinations still on target to reach 80% full dose by end of year. After a post-New Year peak I expect numbers to fall fairly quickly. Estimate for end of each month so I can monitor progress (000s):
Nov: 1,790 Dec: 1,865 (+-5) Jan: 1,947 (+-10) Feb: 1,985 (+-20) Mar: 2,005 (+-30) Apr: 2,020 (+-40)
Readjust due to numbers leveling off when I initially expected to drop further. Still expect a long term drop.

Cases above 2,000/day and plateaued slightly earlier than expected. 
My estimate for end of November (from Oct 25th) now looks  ~10-15k too low, so I am bringing the target date forward a couple of weeks.
So far the crowd looks about right.

At this stage in my thinking I answered the question by doing a crude extrapolation from the Statista web site:
 https://www.statista.com/statistics/1107094/covid19-cumulative-cases-by-date-of-symptom-onset-canada/.  Caveat: Could be a rookie forecasting move on my part as because we all know, the past doesn't necessarily predict the future.

"Before 24 December 2021" is virtually impossible by now but I am not very optimistic at all. Numbers are plateauing and winter is coming... I expect that numbers will rise again during the next weeks, so "Between 23 January 2022 and 21 February 2022" is the most realistic option for me. I think the crowd forecast is too optimistic.
Cases are rather contained with more activity in smaller provinces. I think it will take some time to reach 2MM.

1.725m
Cases nudging down to 2k per day
275k to go
3k / day = 92 days = 5 feb
2.5k / day = 110 days = 23 Feb
2k / day = 137 days = 13 mar
1.5k / day = 183 days = after 23 apr
Cases have already stopped declining, at least for now. I'm starting to wonder whether cases will increase (gently) from now through early Jan. You, @paulm?
Cases are going down. Daily average is around 2000 cases daily but vaccination rates are still going up. Children will be vaccinated, and booster
good vaccine uptake in most populous provinces, no significant 4th wave in ON and BC

The last wave in Canada was due to delta variant. For the last 3 months delta has been the dominant variant in Canada [1]. With high level of vaccination and delta variant washing through the population, I am not expecting any further waves bigger than the previous waves.  [1] https://ourworldindata.org/explorers/coronavirus-data-explorer?time=2021-04-05..latest&facet=none&Metric=Delta+variant+%28share%29&Interval=Cumulative&Relative+to+Population=false&Align+outbreaks=false&country=~CAN
At 2000 cases per day, 2M will be reached in about 6 mos.
Baseline forecast ends up at 1.98M on April 22. Risk of high transmission is greatest before Feb.
Cases are dropping and vaccination rates continue to increase.   Data treads at:   https://covid19.healthdata.org/canada?view=infections-testing&tab=trend&test=infections

Average case rates required to hit 2M by the bucket dates:
12/24 - avg 5k
1/23 - avg 3.3k
2/22 - avg 2.5k
3/24 - avg 2k
4/23 - avg 1.6k Delta peaked around 4.4k cases, with an average closer to 2k. So - to hit the 12/24 bucket would take something new, far more severe and fast-spreading than Delta. This is roughly as likely as an entirely new pandemic, which is around 1/50 years or 0.3% in a 2 month bucket. Rounding up to 1%. 1/22 and 2/21 buckets at 2% and 3% following similar logic. 3/23 and onwards are more interesting since either one long-circulating delta-like variant or multiple shorter-lived delta-like variants could reach them. Figuring one variant per year on average, with an average trajectory similar to Delta's, and considering there are no variants looking likely to do anything impactful in the immediate future, I'll consider the period of interest as 11/23-4/23 and put the odds of two happening in a 5 month period at very roughly 17%, with the spread leaning towards the later bucket.

To reach the mark by 21 February it must be at around 2.500 on average. This seems to be quite reasonable to me. Vaccination rate is high in Canada, but last year the delta variant was not there and we had numbers considerably higher than 2.500 during those months. There are many breakthrough infections in my setting (Germany) and I am quite sure this will be also the case in Canada. Numbers are declining at the moment, but especially during the winter numbers will more likely rise than fall. I do not really understand why the Crowd Forecast is so utterly optimistic. We should not just look at the current trend, but at the base rate. I give it 55 % before 21 February. I think the likelyhood is even higher, but I hesitate because the Crowd Forecast is clearly in the other direction.

With new cases in Alberta and Sask dropping (Alberta might be tapering off), but BC/Ontario/Quebec fairly steady, I'm foreseeing a drop to around 2-2.2k cases in the near future. After that, there are the holidays, vaccination of <12 year olds, increased travel, and whatever else the future brings. I'm leaning towards cases slowly trending down just because of vaccination, and so far there don't seem to be any new variants of concern.  2.6k (current level) daily cases puts us at mid-February
2.2k puts us at the beginning of March
2k puts us at the end of March
1.6k puts us at end of April, but not sure if we'll get there without some other measures

I previously stated that the UK was more highly vaccinated than Canada, which isn't strictly correct. Canada is 73.2% fully vaccinated (83.6% of eligible population), which includes nearly 78% of 12-17 year olds, whereas the UK is at under 60% for 16-17yrs and under 20% 12-15 yrs. These are the age groups where transmission and cases are highest in the UK, so I think this bodes well for Canada having a shallower wave over winter than I first thought. 
The decline in cases is slowing in the most populous provinces, but only BC and SK appear to have plateaued. For context BC currently contributes over 20% all cases. So I think the decline will continue at a slower rate over the next few weeks, then progress to a more shallow winter wave than first forecast, pushing the likelihood of the last two bins higher in probability. Bin5 could become the favourite if things go well. I'm expecting 1,775,000 at end of November as a benchmark.

Rt increases in fall and winter (empirical observation from last year, restrictions held constant); this is what respiratory viruses do. So I think that at a minimum, the downside of the Delta wave will be prolonged. Vaccination levels are high and slowly increasing, and more kids are likely to be vaccinated soon. Mask mandates will help, too. A recent modeling paper suggested that unvaccinated people would get Covid every 16 months on average (range 3 months to 5 years), in the absence of mitigations; thus, it wouldn't be unreasonable to expect that substantially less than half of the unvaccinated people who have had Covid will get it again before April 23, 2022. I'm not sure what to think here. I wouldn't expect to see too far over 100k more cases by the end of the year. The seasonal peak for SARSCoV2 transmission seems to be in January in the N Hemisphere, so let's add some number of cases in bin 2. I wouldn't expect too much really big to go on after that for a while unless a new variant emerges that escapes a lot of immunity. By mid February, would it be too much to dare to hope that cases are <500/day? I could easily picture this question resolving in the last bin, but there's so much uncertainty, especially when it comes to variants, that I'll spread my forecast more widely. @paulm, aloha! For once, I think my forecast is slightly more optimistic than yours!

The current declining trend should continue a few weeks but winter, Christmas and New Year are bound to lead to increased close social interaction and more cases. They should make it below 1800/day before that, and in their favour are high and rising vaccination levels (over 80% by Christmas),  mask mandates, sparse population and the possibility of doses for under 11s.
The UK has a higher vax level (this needs qualifying) but also mixed messaging, almost no masking rules, a more dense population and a higher testing rate that highlights the bulk of cases are now children 9-18yrs. Judging from the previous year and a quick comparison I think an increase through December is likely, with the earliest deadline near end of Feb, but more likely during March if they manage well. End of April seems a little optimistic, but good for them if they make it to bin5.

1,695,914 as of Oct 21.  7 day avg 2,858 and declining. Most of the worst offenders are getting sorted and vaccine passports are in most if not all provinces with a national one just being announced. Juvenile vaccine (ages 5-11) has been purchased for first dose of all children in that age range and some provinces have started booking appointments. Although there will be more indoor activity mask mandates are still widely in place and vaccination rates are still climbing. At current trend its 106 days out (Feb 6), which is the earliest I'd consider. But it's down by 1/3 in the last month (mostly on drops in AB, SK, QC and ON. BC, MB and The Maritimes have been fairly stable. Trend will likely drop another 20% over the next month, which would put it mid-March. Children's vaccine could further slow it and a rapid roll out would further help. With 6 months until April 23 the rate would need to be below 1675, which may be possible with high uptake of the children's vaccine. I'm thinking the most likely case is a bit before but will throw a bit of optimism in the mix. https://globalnews.ca/news/8286078/covid-coronavirus-vaccine-passport-certificate-federal-travel/

1.7m cases so far according to ourworldindata, can’t get the Canadian site to work.
3k cases per day
This is 100 days to get to 2m which = 31 Jan
At 2k cases per day this is 150 days or mid April. Cases are dropping from 3k but any winter surge will bring back up, so at the moment I think cases will on average stick somewhere in the 2k to 3k range giving somewhere in Feb to April as the most likely time. 23 April is 182 days away, which means average has to be below 1.6k per day every day to pass this date.  Every day higher now decreases the average needed making it less likely.  So there needs to be a quick drop to 1k and cases to stay there to get past 23 April.
Adjusting to more accurately capture the bimodal nature of the likely outcomes.

I made a basic cyclical trend model using the last four waves to train the fifth. My takeaway is that if another wave hits this winter, it will drop off in Feb-March. Therefore, the outcome becomes less likely as you get closer to the close date (because the case counts get smaller). It's a weird "either it happens soon or it doesn't happen" situation. It's not a sophisticated model, but I found that insight from it to be interesting.

If rates of infection over the last month continued, this would happen no later than end of January. Since cases will go up over the winter with very high certainty, this means resolution sometime in January. If cases matched or exceed last year, sometime before Christmas, and we are already at higher rates than this time last year.

Most likely to occur during the next wave, which should start in early December. However, with the current levels of immunity, I expect the next wave to be smaller — unless a variant emerges. Therefore, I'm heavily weighting the likelihood that the numbers stay below 2 million at close.
